clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Sodium Bicarbonate on Postoperative Renal Function in Infective Endocarditis Patients Undergoing Open Heart Surgery

oversight_info.authority: South Korea: Korea Food and Drug Administration (KFDA)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of study is to test whether perioperative sodium bicarbonate infusion can prevent acute kidney injury following open heart surgery in infective endocarditis patients.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Pharmacodynamics Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of the incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury in patients with or without sodium bicarbonate
primary_outcome.description: acute kidney injury based on the AKIN criteria ; increase in serum creatinine of 0.3 mg/dL or >50 percent developing over <48 hours

intervention.description: 0.5 mmol/kg for 1 hr, and then 0.15 mmol/kg/h for 23 hrs The infusion of study drug is started after anesthesia induction and continued until 24 hours after surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adult patients over the age of 20 scheduled for open heart surgery for infective endocarditis
Exclusion Criteria:
- end stage renal disease (serum creatinine concentration > 300 Î¼mol/L)
- on dialysis
- chronic moderate to high dose corticosteroid therapy (> 10 mg/day prednisolon or equivalent)
- preoperative severe hypernatremia (Na+ > 150 mmol/L), alkalemia (PH > 7.50), or pulmonary edema
- neurocognitive dysfunction

facility.name: Department of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine, Yonsei University College of Medicine

clinical_study.keyword: sodium bicarbonate, renal function, infective endocarditis, open heart surgery
